t: Proverbs 24
Don’t*pn envy the evil or*ln desire to be with them,
for*ln their hearts plan violence, and*ln their words stir up trouble.
A*pn house is built by wisdom, and*ln it is established by understanding;
by*ln knowledge the rooms are filled with*ln every precious and beautiful treasure.
A*pn wise warrior is better than a strong one, and*ln a man of knowledge than one of strength;
for*ln you should wage war with sound guidance — victory*ln comes with many counselors.
Wisdom*pn is inaccessible to a fool; he*ln does not open his mouth at the city gate.
The*pn one who plots evil will*ln be called a schemer.
A*ln foolish scheme is sin, and*ln a mocker is detestable to people.
If*pn you do nothing in a difficult time, your*ln strength is limited.
Rescue*ln those being taken off to death, and*ln save those stumbling toward slaughter.
If*ln you say, “But we didn’t know about this,” won’t*ln he who weighs hearts consider it? Won’t*ln he who protects your life know? Won’t*ln he repay a person according to his work?
Eat*pn honey, my son, for it is good, and*ln the honeycomb is sweet to your palate;
realize*ln that wisdom is the same for you. If*ln you find it, you will have a future, and*ln your hope will never fade.
Don’t*pn set an ambush, you wicked one, at*ln the camp of the righteous man; don’t*ln destroy his dwelling.
Though*ln a righteous person falls seven times, he*ln will get up, but*ln the wicked will stumble into ruin.
Don’t*pn gloat when your enemy falls, and*ln don’t let your heart rejoice when he stumbles,
or*ln the Lord*s will see, be displeased, and*ln turn his wrath away from him.
Don’t*pn be agitated by evildoers, and*ln don’t envy the wicked.
For*ln the evil have no future; the*ln lamp of the wicked will be put out.
My*pn son, fear the Lord,*s as well as the king, and*ln don’t associate with rebels,
for*ln destruction will come suddenly from them; who*ln knows what distress these two can bring?
These*pn sayings also belong to the wise: It*ln is not good to show partiality in judgment.
Whoever*ln says to the guilty, “You are innocent”— peoples*ln will curse him, and nations will denounce him;
but*ln it will go well with those who convict the guilty, and*ln a generous blessing will come to them.
He*pn who gives an honest answer gives*ln a kiss on the lips.
Complete*pn your outdoor work, and prepare your field; afterward,*ln build your house.
Don’t*pn testify against your neighbor without cause. Don’t*ln deceive with your lips.
Don’t*ln say, “I’ll do to him what he did to me; I’ll*ln repay the man for what he has done.”
I*pn went by the field of a slacker and*ln by the vineyard of one lacking sense.
Thistles*ln had come up everywhere, weeds*ln covered the ground, and*ln the stone wall was ruined.
I*ln saw, and took it to heart; I*ln looked, and received instruction:
a*ln little sleep, a little slumber, a*ln little folding of the arms to rest,
and*ln your poverty will come like a robber, and*ln your need, like a bandit.
